Title: What is a Pip? (Forex in 60s) #1
Script: Let’s break down What is a Pip? (Forex in 60s) #1 so you can trade it with a calm plan. Because clarity beats guesses—rules make you repeat good behavior. Step 1: Use the daily chart to mark clean support and resistance zones. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Risk 0.5%–1% per trade; size stops with ATR so a normal wiggle doesn’t knock you out. Example: if ATR doubles and London just opened, widen stops, reduce size, and look for momentum follow‑through. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Title: 1% Risk Rule (Forex in 60s) #6
Script: Let’s break down 1% Risk Rule (Forex in 60s) #6 so you can trade it with a calm plan. This matters when markets speed up and emotions rise. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Keep reward at least equal to risk; aim for 1:1.5 or better to compound. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: In a trend, enter on pullbacks that hold above/below a moving average or prior swing. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Step 1: Check the higher timeframe to label **trend** or **range**. Step 2: Wait for price to react at a level—rejection wick, break-and-retest, or strong close. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Wait for price to react at a level—rejection wick, break-and-retest, or strong close. Keep reward at least equal to risk; aim for 1:1.5 or better to compound. Example: on a range day, fade edges with tight stops; on a trend day, ride pullbacks and hold winners. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Title: Take‑Profit Basics (Forex in 60s) #585
Script: Here’s a quick, practical lesson on Take‑Profit Basics (Forex in 60s) #585. This matters when markets speed up and emotions rise. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Risk 0.5%–1% per trade; size stops with ATR so a normal wiggle doesn’t knock you out. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Step 1: Use the daily chart to mark clean support and resistance zones. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Keep reward at least equal to risk; aim for 1:1.5 or better to compound. Example: if ATR doubles and London just opened, widen stops, reduce size, and look for momentum follow‑through. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Title: Risk‑to‑Reward (R:R) (Forex in 60s) #791
Script: Here’s a quick, practical lesson on Risk‑to‑Reward (R:R) (Forex in 60s) #791. With a checklist, you avoid random entries and protect your account. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: In a trend, enter on pullbacks that hold above/below a moving average or prior swing. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: on a range day, fade edges with tight stops; on a trend day, ride pullbacks and hold winners. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: In a trend, enter on pullbacks that hold above/below a moving average or prior swing. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Script: If you master Support & Resistance (Forex in 60s) #1032, your decisions get clearer and calmer. Because clarity beats guesses—rules make you repeat good behavior. Step 1: Use the daily chart to mark clean support and resistance zones. Step 2: In a trend, enter on pullbacks that hold above/below a moving average or prior swing. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: on a range day, fade edges with tight stops; on a trend day, ride pullbacks and hold winners. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources.

Title: 1% Risk Rule (Forex in 60s) #1166
Script: Here’s a quick, practical lesson on 1% Risk Rule (Forex in 60s) #1166. Because clarity beats guesses—rules make you repeat good behavior. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Wait for price to react at a level—rejection wick, break-and-retest, or strong close. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Keep reward at least equal to risk; aim for 1:1.5 or better to compound. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Title: Trend vs Range (Forex in 60s) #1473
Script: Trend vs Range (Forex in 60s) #1473: simple rules that keep you safe and consistent. With a checklist, you avoid random entries and protect your account. Step 1: Use the daily chart to mark clean support and resistance zones. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Risk 0.5%–1% per trade; size stops with ATR so a normal wiggle doesn’t knock you out. Example: if ATR doubles and London just opened, widen stops, reduce size, and look for momentum follow‑through. Step 1: Check the higher timeframe to label **trend** or **range**. Step 2: In a trend, enter on pullbacks that hold above/below a moving average or prior swing. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if ATR doubles and London just opened, widen stops, reduce size, and look for momentum follow‑through. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Subscribe to **Forex Voyage** for daily lessons and see **ZenithFX.com** for resources. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Wait for price to react at a level—rejection wick, break-and-retest, or strong close. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: on a range day, fade edges with tight stops; on a trend day, ride pullbacks and hold winners. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: on a range day, fade edges with tight stops; on a trend day, ride pullbacks and hold winners. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.

Script: If you master Swap/Overnight Fees (Forex in 60s) #1677, your decisions get clearer and calmer. Because clarity beats guesses—rules make you repeat good behavior. Keep reward at least equal to risk; aim for 1:1.5 or better to compound. Example: if ATR doubles and London just opened, widen stops, reduce size, and look for momentum follow‑through. Step 1: Draw yesterday’s high/low and the current session’s opening range. Step 2: Enter only at your level; skip the middle of the range. Place stops where your idea is invalid, not where you “hope” it holds. Size with ATR. Example: if USD is strong across pairs, prefer USD-trend setups and skip counter‑trend stabs. Checklist: higher timeframe ➜ mark levels ➜ session context ➜ trigger ➜ manage risk. Save this, subscribe to **Forex Voyage**, and visit **ZenithFX.com** for tools and education. Tip: journal each trade—screenshot entry, stop, reason, and exit. Patterns appear faster when you review.
